title: model_svimixed.SmoothModel
text:
model_svimixed.SmoothModel(
    self
    n_state
    random_ind
    fixed_ind
    obs_times
    sde_times
)
The variational distribution is given by \[\begin{equation}
\begin{aligned}
    \theta \mid y_{0:N} &\sim N(\mu(y_{0:N}), \Sigma(y_{0:N})) \\
    \eta \mid y_{0:N}, \theta &\sim N(A(y_{0:N}) \theta + b(y_{0:N}), V(y_{0:N})) \\
    x_{0:N} \mid y_{0:N}, \eta  &\sim N\big(\mu_{x} (y_{0:N}, \eta), \Sigma_{x}(y_{0:N}, \eta)\big).
\end{aligned}
\end{equation}\] where \(x\) are the latents, \(y\) are the observations, \(\theta\) are the SDE parameters, and \(\eta\) are the random effects. The random-effects are modelled via a neural network given by \[
A, b, V = \textnormal{NN}_{\eta}(y_{0:N}),
\] where random effects are simulated via \(\eta = A \theta + b + V \epsilon\). The latents are modelled by a RNN give by \[
\mu_{x}, \Sigma_{x} = \textnormal{RNN}(y_{0:N}, \eta)
\] by fitting the Kalman filtering parameters. On the backward pass we use the conditional Gaussian model given by \[\begin{equation}
\begin{aligned}
    x_n \mid x_{n+1} \sim N(\mu^\prime_n, \Sigma^\prime_n)
\end{aligned}
\end{equation}\] where we fit a neural network to find \[
\mu^\prime_n, \Sigma^\prime_n = \textnormal{NN}(x_{n+1}, \mu_{x}, \Sigma_{x}).
\]











Name
Type
Description
Default




n_state
int
Dimension of the latent at each time point.
required


random_ind
jax.Array
Indices of the parameters used to generate the random effects.
required


fixed_ind
jax.Array
Indices of the fixed-effect parameters.
required


obs_times
jax.Array
Observation time points.
required


sde_times
jax.Array
Discretization time points used to sample the latents.
required









Name
Description




simulate
Simulate \(\theta\), \(\eta\), and \(x\) using IEVI and compute





model_svimixed.SmoothModel.simulate(key, params, y_meas, x_init)
Simulate \(\theta\), \(\eta\), and \(x\) using IEVI and compute \(\log q(\theta) + \log q(\eta \mid \theta) + \log q(x \mid \eta)\).











Name
Type
Description
Default




key
jax.PRNGKey
PRNG key.
required


params
dict
Dictionary holding the neural network parameters and other parameters necessary to simulate \(\theta\) and \(x\).
required


y_meas
jax.Array
Observations.
required


x_init
jax.Array
Initial guess of the latent.
required














Name
Type
Description




x
jax.Array
Latents at the SDE time points.


theta
jax.Array
SDE parameters.


eta
jax.Array
Random effects.


logpdf
float
\(\log q(\theta) + \log q(\eta \mid \theta) + \log q(x \mid \eta)\).

title: model_ryder.RyderModel
text:
model_ryder.RyderModel(
    self
    n_state
    obs_times
    sde_times
    obs_mat
    restrict=False
)
This module implement the RNN method of Ryder at al.Â (2018)
RNN takes on the features:
where \(t_0, ... t_N\) is the SDE time grid and \(t'_0, ..., t'_M\) is the observation time grid. Here \(t'_m\) is the next observation time greater than \(t_n\).
The RNN returns \(\alpha, \beta^{1/2}\) where simulation is done via \(x_n = x_{n-1} + \alpha \Delta t + \beta^{1/2} \sqrt \Delta t \epsilon\).











Name
Type
Description
Default




n_state
int
Dimension of the latent at each time point.
required


obs_times
jax.Array
The observation time points.
required


sde_times
jax.Array
The discretization time points used to sample the latents.
required


obs_mat
jax.Array
The fixed observation matrix assumed in Ryder.
required


restrict
bool
Flag for determining whether the simulated \(x\) needs to be positive.
False









Name
Description




simulate
Simulate \(x\) using Ryder and compute \(\log q(x \mid \theta)\).


simulate_theta
Simulate \(\theta\) using the variation distribution. Also compute \(\log q(\theta)\).


simulate_theta_rnn
Simulate \(\theta\) using the variation distribution assuming a RNN. Also compute \(\log q(\theta)\).

title: IEVI: Information-Efficient Variational Inference for SDEs
text:
IEVI is a variational inference method for SDEs that approximates the intractable latent posterior. Compared to other variational inference methods, IEVI captures not only the correct conditional dependence structure but also the correct information flow from the observations to the intractable posterior.




This will clone the repo into a subfolder ievi, from where you (i) issue the git clone command and (ii) install the package from source.
git clone https://github.com/mlysy/ievi
cd ievi
pip install .



From within ievi/docs:
quartodoc build
quarto render

title: model_svi.SmoothModel
text:
model_svi.SmoothModel(self, n_state, obs_times, sde_times)
The variational distribution is given by \[\begin{equation}
\begin{aligned}
    \theta \mid y_{0:N} &\sim N(\mu(y_{0:N}), \Sigma(y_{0:N})) \\
    x_{0:N} \mid y_{0:N}, \theta  &\sim N\big(\mu_{x} (y_{0:N}, \theta), \Sigma_{x}(y_{0:N}, \theta)\big).
\end{aligned}
\end{equation}\] where \(x\) are the latents, \(y\) are the observations, and \(\theta\) are the SDE parameters. The underlying RNN provides \[
\mu_{x}, \Sigma_{x} = \textnormal{RNN}(y_{0:N}, \theta)
\] by fitting the Kalman filtering parameters. On the backward pass we use the conditional Gaussian model given by \[\begin{equation}
\begin{aligned}
    x_n \mid x_{n+1} &\sim N(\mu^\prime_n, \Sigma^\prime_n)
\end{aligned}
\end{equation}\] where we fit a neural network to find \[
\mu^\prime_n, \Sigma^\prime_n = \textnormal{NN}(x_{n+1}, \mu_{x}, \Sigma_{x}).
\]

Type
Description
Default

int
Dimension of the latent at each time point.
required


obs_times

The observation time points.
required

required

Description

Simulate \(x\) using IEVI and compute \(\log q(x \mid \theta)\).


simulate_theta
Simulate \(\theta\) using the variation distribution. Also compute \(\log q(\theta)\).
